I'm not entirely sure this is a parallel so correct me if I am wrong, and also my understanding is VERY limited, mostly based on my personal experiences, but it sounds a lot like a concept I am quite familiar with that has....unfortunate connotations.

The concept I am referring to is "gaman" a Japanese phrase/saying essentially meaning something along the lines of "endure, don't stick out, bend with the wind, don't complain, etc."

The reason why it's an issue is that gaman was and is so laced with the culture and the idea that you shouldn't voice your concerns, that the Japanese had been persecuted and they basically did very little to protest it. Additionally, the idea of gaman, from my understanding, is a contributor to the suicide rates in Japan, since there is a desire to not voice dissent. This can be harmful.

I agree that violent dissent is not the way to go. That's something I can definitely agree with. But I think it is also important to highlight that sometimes, standing firm does a lot more than just kind of passively mentioning something in hopes things will change. Voicing change, petitioning for it, and taking a stand is WORLDS different than flinging a bunch of insults around or mindless accusations.

If something needs to be changed for the better, or that is an opinion, that opinion should be presented with reasonable examples and suggestions. But it also should not be written off as "players not knowing what they are talking about" or "entitled players are whining". Such things tend to irritate those with actual concerns, and that can have a damaging effect on relations to come to either a change or compromise as well.
